review.des: I've recently learned the glory that is ramen. Party of four showed up on a Saturday afternoon and were seated almost immediately. We each had a bowl of ramen. Amazing! We all finished our bowls. Highly suggest this place and I'm already planning a return trip.

First stop in Chi after checking in and spotted this on Yelp. Right by our hotel garage and short walk. This was a stop for our family of five and varying tastes.

We started with a seafood gyoza that was special for the day. Everyone ate it up...especially the picky 9 year old. We all ordered ramens and one of the fried chicken buns. All delicious!

We were seated toward the back in a nice booth. One of the bathrooms was out of order. Quick and friendly service.

I didn't actually go visit in person so can't say much about parking or the interior but my sister and I got it delivered to our hotel room the first night. We both got the kimchi fried chicken ramen and it was pretty good! Everything came relatively quickly and the soup and ingredients were separate so that the noodles and chicken weren't soggy and the soup was still hot-ish. Definitely would go back again to try the ramen and matcha cream puff in person

Ramen San was the first ramen restaurant I've been ever been to. So with nothing to compare it to, I thought everything about it was fantastic. The atmosphere, the food and the drinks. Since then, I've been to Ramen San for both lunch and dinner!

The express lunch is the perfect amount of food. It comes with salad, a rice bowl of your choosing and a main dish of your choosing. I always go for the skirt steak rice place and the tonkotzu for my main dish. The Tonkotsu is a ramen bowl with pork broth, chashu pork and a molten egg. It's rich and salty - everything you're looking for in a bowl of ramen. I think the best part about ramen san is the noodles. Wavy style noodles made their their specs over at Sun Noodle consisting of flour, water and kansui.

Dinner is a whole other game. I go straight to the buns. When I take friends from out of town, it's my power-move to order all three buns on the menu before they get the chance to glance at the menu. Their quick and seriously amazing, setting the tone for the dining experience. The fried chicken bun is my favorite - basically an Asian style chicken sandwich. After that, ramen. It honestly doesn't matter which ramen you order as long as it's got something you like! If not, throw on some add-ons. You're guaranteed to be full after your bowl - be sure to wear your hear up, and short sleeves. Because it gets pretty warm once the ramen sweats start up.

Give the drinks and desserts a try if you'd like! All of them are noteworthy and I haven't had a bad experience with them yet. When I go, I'm there for the buns and ramen, so I forgo the sides and drinks. All reasonably priced - a great date night spot, business lunch spot, and perfect for visitors coming from a not-so-ramen-fluent city.

In my judgmental snobbery for authentic ramen, I have qualms when:
1) it feels like a club with hip-hop or rap blasting in the background
2) it feels like very fusionized with a trendy full bar in plain sight
3) it feels like it's catered to n00dle n00bs with explanations of ramen ingredients on the menu

Unfortunately Ramen-san hit all 3 of my red flags, but fortunately Ramen-san turned out to serve delicious and (fairly) authentic ramen. The menu features a range of millennials' favorite Asian food, including several types of ramen ranging from vegetarian shiitake to the epic Sumo Bowl with wontons, as well as a handful of baos. The dessert of hot donuts with creme anglaise is popular too and looks uniquely beignet-style. They even have okonomiyaki for weekend brunch and late night fried rice for the drunchies.

The boo got the Tonkotsu, which contained all the essentials (in terms of eating as well as photographing) of chashu pork, half molten egg, scallion, and seaweed. For $14 it's on the pricier side though within the range I'm used to for more upscale ramen.
- The portions are also rather impressive, starring 3 generous slabs of melt-in-your-mouth spice-rubbed pork belly
- While the molten egg had the right consistency, I would have liked it steeped in sauce like traditional ajitama
- Noodles are the wavy egg-based type and had a decently springy texture
- Tonkotsu broth was well done, with prominent pork flavors but not too salty or thick

I was enticed by the Special of the night, which our server described as carnitas style pork with scallions in tonkotsu broth. The mystery price tag turned out to be $15, which was quite reasonable. Although the concept of combining carnitas with ramen is interesting, the pork wasn't the soft guilty-pleasure pulled pork that I was expecting but rather a dried jerky-like take. I appreciate the novelty, but in my opinion it was less than practical since it was very chewy and the dried pork wasn't ideal for soaking up broth.

Despite my initial disapproval of the fusion-like elements, I did enjoy the hip ambiance which made the place feel very alive. The dim lighting is cool (though possibly not the best for food pictures), and the tall communal wooden tables add street food vibes as a nod to the origins of ramen.

Stepped into Ramen-san over a chilly weekend for brunch. We ordered the tonkotsu ramen with additional chili peppers and the beef brisket octopus okonomiyaki. The ramen broth was solid. I just wish the bowl came with more ingredients rather than being charged for customization. The okonomiyaki was a pretty good deal for $6. The bonito flakes and octopus were a bit fishy for my liking, but open to have it again the future.
